handDesc.p: This inscription uses an unusual shape of basic punctuation, which does not look like a comma but rather like a simple vertical bar or daṇḍa. The pasangan s, ṣ and p are written in the modern fashion on the same line, instead of below the line as it is still usually the case in the Majapahit period. We observe two shapes of anusvāra in this inscription, with the alternative round shape appearing for instance l. 2v5. The scribe uses two ways of forming akṣara lā: with tarung placed to the right of the akṣara, most frequent with tarung written in “superscript” form: 3r1 prajālāṅkarā

div.p: by royal consecration name, Dyah Hayam Vuruk, being accompanied by the order of Her Majesty the illustrious Tribhuvanottuṅgarājadevī Jayaviṣṇuvardhanī, an image of the Goddess who is auspicious for all kings i.e. Śrī-Lakṣmī?, splendid by the glory of her charming and captivating knowledges, in union like an Ardhanārīśvara along with His Majesty the illustrious Lord Kr̥tavardhana, adorned by the obeisance of all kings, together with the order of Her Majesty the illustrious Vijayadevī, a perfect ornament of heroism mounted in the royal diadem of a Great King, possessed of a mind sprouting with all virtues, in union like an Ardhanārīśvara together with His Majesty the illustrious Lord Vijayarājasa, adorned by his heroism on the battlefield.

In each case their order were received by the Three rakryan Great Ministers, i.e. the rakryan great minister of Hino, Dyah Īśvara, the rakryan great minister of Sirikan, Dyah Ipo, the rakryan great minister of Halu, Dyah Kañciṅ,

Having contemplated the reasons for the strength of the reliability adhimukti of both litigants , this is how their litigation was settled by the judges who are steadfast in the keeping of the dharma for lawsuits inside the capital. That is the reason why, , together, both litigants appeared respectfully one after another (?, mampak-āmpak) to report to all the ranking officials in the advisory council, presenting their respective cases.
As for the testimony suṅan vara-varah of Aki Santana, with the byname Śaraṇa, along with all his companions, ki Karṇa, with the byname Manākara, Ajaran Reka, ki Siran, ki Jumput:

“We own this land called Manah i Manuk. The distribution kahayvan of the irrigated rice fields: in Aḍavuṅ 1 lirih; in Berəm, 1 lirih; in Pajənon south of the habitations, 2 lirih; in Pajənon a garden of 1 kuñci; in Paṅeran a garden of 1 kuñci; in Tiga Thani the distribution of the irrigated rice fields is: in Vareṅ 1 lirih, the distribution in Valuntas, 10 lirih; in Tiga Thani a garden of 1 kuñci. 16 lirih were given away by my ancestors to the “place of recluses” of Pakaṇḍaṅan; to the maṇḍala-order in Kukub, 2 lirih were given; 1 lirih was given to the jaṅgan rural doctors, see also SKK 11.24 hayaṅ ñaho di (568)pupuja di saṅgar ma, patah, puja daun, gәlar (569)palajaṅ, puja kәmbaṅ, (570)ñampiṅan liṅga, (571)ṅomean saṅ hyaṅ, siṅ savatәk muja ma, (572)jaṅgan taña. for Pigeaud in Paṅle.
and besides that, land which was enjoyed by those who pay up taxes: 33 lirih, in total 67 lirih. This has been in continuous possession/enjoyment sthiti-bukti from my ancestors: my father, my grandfather, great-grandfather, great-great-grandfather, great-great-great-great-grandfather, great-great-great-great-great-grandfather. There is no concrete evidence suvanda, for this enjoyment has existed from time immemorial. It has for clear evidence the existence of the pious foundation of my ancestors, namely the pavilion at the maṇḍala of Kasəḍahan, dated 919 Śaka, which name is said to be the “Vayu tree in the middle” (vayu anəṅah). That dates from the same time as the irrigated rice-field. And moreover, these are no irrigated ricefields of the relatives established at Sīma Tiga beyond the boundary of Pakaṇḍaṅan. It does not yield tahil, it is not liable to be designated, it should not be used as a tool by the region (deśa).
